conclusion: Two identical books A and B, each weighing 5N, are divided into equal parts and stacked alternately on a smooth table. Book A is fixed, and a horizontal force F is applied to pull out book B.
The problem involves finding the coefficient of kinetic friction Î¼ between any two sheets of paper in the two books.
The table shows the number of trials, the number of book divisions, and the corresponding force F in Newtons.
Trial 1: 2 divisions, F = 4.5N; Trial 2: 4 divisions, F = 10.5N; Trial 3: 8 divisions, F = 22.5N; Trial 4: 16 divisions, F = 46.5N; Trial n: Page-by-page proofreading, F = 190.5N.
The force F required to pull out book B depends on the frictional forces between the pages of the two books.
As the number of divisions doubles, the force roughly doubles as well.
The force F increases as the number of divisions increases, indicating more interfaces and more frictional forces.
The force F is proportional to the number of divisions.
